annotation.spannedText: Adults born before 1970 can be presumed to have acquired natural immunity to measles; however, non-immune health care workers, travellers and military personnel should receive MMR vaccine, regardless of year of birth

annotation.spannedText: Routine childhood immunization: administer two doses of measles-containing vaccine (MMR or MMRV); the first dose at 12 to 15 months of age and the second dose at 18 months of age or any time thereafter, but should be given not later than around school entry

annotation.spannedText: MMR and MMRV vaccines are safe and effective

annotation.spannedText: Two doses of measles-containing vaccine should be given for routine immunization of children and for immunization of children and adolescents who have missed measles immunization on the routine schedule

annotation.spannedText: Children and adults lacking adequate documentation of immunization should be considered unimmunized and started on an immunization schedule appropriate for their age and risk factors, unless known to be immune based on laboratory testing

classMention.mentionClass: Children and adults lacking adequate documentation of immunization should be considered unimmunized and started on an immunization schedule appropriate for their age and risk factors, unless known to be immune based on laboratory testing

annotation.spannedText: Immunity to measles, mumps and rubella should be reviewed in women of reproductive age, and vaccination should be recommended to non-pregnant susceptible women

classMention.mentionClass: Immunity to measles, mumps and rubella should be reviewed in women of reproductive age, and vaccination should be recommended to non-pregnant susceptible women

annotation.spannedText: Ideally, the immunization status of women intending to become pregnant should be reviewed and vaccines updated as necessary prior to conception

classMention.mentionClass: Ideally, the immunization status of women intending to become pregnant should be reviewed and vaccines updated as necessary prior to conception

annotation.spannedText: Women should delay pregnancy by at least 28 days following vaccination with a live vaccine

classMention.mentionClass: Women should delay pregnancy by at least 28 days following vaccination with a live vaccine

annotation.spannedText: MMR and MMRV vaccines should generally not be given during pregnancy because of the theoretical risk of disease transmission to the fetus; however, there is no evidence demonstrating a teratogenic or other risk from such vaccines

classMention.mentionClass: MMR and MMRV vaccines should generally not be given during pregnancy because of the theoretical risk of disease transmission to the fetus; however, there is no evidence demonstrating a teratogenic or other risk from such vaccines

annotation.spannedText: Inadvertent immunization with MMR vaccine is not a reason for pregnancy termination. In some situations, potential benefits of MMR vaccination may outweigh risks such as during measles or rubella outbreaks, in which case vaccination may be considered

classMention.mentionClass: Inadvertent immunization with MMR vaccine is not a reason for pregnancy termination. In some situations, potential benefits of MMR vaccination may outweigh risks such as during measles or rubella outbreaks, in which case vaccination may be considered

annotation.spannedText: Susceptible residents of long-term care facilities should receive measles, mumps and rubella-containing vaccine as well as all routine immunizations appropriate for their age and risk factors

classMention.mentionClass: Susceptible residents of long-term care facilities should receive measles, mumps and rubella-containing vaccine as well as all routine immunizations appropriate for their age and risk factors

annotation.spannedText: In general, immunocompromised persons should not receive live vaccines because of the risk of disease caused by the vaccine strains

classMention.mentionClass: In general, immunocompromised persons should not receive live vaccines because of the risk of disease caused by the vaccine strains

annotation.spannedText: When considering immunization of an immunocompromised person with a live vaccine, approval from the individualís attending physician should be obtained before vaccination

classMention.mentionClass: When considering immunization of an immunocompromised person with a live vaccine, approval from the individualís attending physician should be obtained before vaccination

annotation.spannedText: People who have a suspicious history for immunodeficiency disorders (e.g., known or suspected family history of congenital immunodeficiency disorder or HIV infection, or history of failure to thrive and recurrent infections) should not be immunized with a live vaccine until they have been fully investigated and T cell dysfunction ruled out

classMention.mentionClass: People who have a suspicious history for immunodeficiency disorders (e.g., known or suspected family history of congenital immunodeficiency disorder or HIV infection, or history of failure to thrive and recurrent infections) should not be immunized with a live vaccine until they have been fully investigated and T cell dysfunction ruled out

annotation.spannedText: A history of negative prenatal screening of the infantís mother for HIV should be obtained before administering a live vaccine

classMention.mentionClass: A history of negative prenatal screening of the infantís mother for HIV should be obtained before administering a live vaccine

annotation.spannedText: If a mother has not received routine prenatal care in Canada, the possibility of undiagnosed HIV infection should be considered

classMention.mentionClass: If a mother has not received routine prenatal care in Canada, the possibility of undiagnosed HIV infection should be considered

annotation.spannedText: MMR vaccine, as appropriate for age, should be considered if the individual is not receiving regular immune globulin replacement therapy which may affect the efficacy of the vaccine

classMention.mentionClass: MMR vaccine, as appropriate for age, should be considered if the individual is not receiving regular immune globulin replacement therapy which may affect the efficacy of the vaccine

annotation.spannedText: Serologic response should be checked after the first dose of MMR vaccine and a second dose should be given 3 months or more after the first dose if there is no seroconversion

classMention.mentionClass: Serologic response should be checked after the first dose of MMR vaccine and a second dose should be given 3 months or more after the first dose if there is no seroconversion

annotation.spannedText: If possible, individuals being considered for solid organ transplantation should receive immunizations recommended for their age before the transplantation is performed

classMention.mentionClass: If possible, individuals being considered for solid organ transplantation should receive immunizations recommended for their age before the transplantation is performed

annotation.spannedText: MMR vaccine should be given at least 4 weeks before solid organ transplantation and, in general, is not recommended after transplantation

classMention.mentionClass: MMR vaccine should be given at least 4 weeks before solid organ transplantation and, in general, is not recommended after transplantation

annotation.spannedText: Vaccination status for measles, mumps and rubella should be reviewed for immunocompetent persons who might be anticipating initiation of immunosuppressive treatments or who have diseases that might lead to immunodeficiency

classMention.mentionClass: Vaccination status for measles, mumps and rubella should be reviewed for immunocompetent persons who might be anticipating initiation of immunosuppressive treatments or who have diseases that might lead to immunodeficiency

annotation.spannedText: If indicated, MMR vaccine should be administered at least 4 weeks before the initiation of immunosuppressive therapy to reduce the risk of disease caused by the vaccine strain

classMention.mentionClass: If indicated, MMR vaccine should be administered at least 4 weeks before the initiation of immunosuppressive therapy to reduce the risk of disease caused by the vaccine strain

annotation.spannedText: A period of at least 4 weeks should elapse between discontinuation of high-dose systemic steroids and the administration of MMR vaccine

classMention.mentionClass: A period of at least 4 weeks should elapse between discontinuation of high-dose systemic steroids and the administration of MMR vaccine

annotation.spannedText: until additional information becomes available, avoidance of MMR vaccines during intermittent or low dose chemotherapy or other immunosuppressive therapy is prudent

annotation.spannedText: B cell enumeration should be normal before vaccination with live vaccines

classMention.mentionClass: B cell enumeration should be normal before vaccination with live vaccines

annotation.spannedText: Vaccination status should be reviewed prior to commencing monoclonal antibodies

classMention.mentionClass: Vaccination status should be reviewed prior to commencing monoclonal antibodies

annotation.spannedText: An infectious disease specialist/immunologist should be consulted for advice on MMR immunization in HIV-infected people

classMention.mentionClass: An infectious disease specialist/immunologist should be consulted for advice on MMR immunization in HIV-infected people

annotation.spannedText: Susceptible household contacts of immunocompromised people should receive a measles-containing vaccine as appropriate for age and risk factors
